math_problem.A3682:
Find all permutations $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_9$ of $1, 2, \ldots, 9$ such that  \[ a_1+a_2+a_3+a_4=a_4+a_5+a_6+a_7= a_7+a_8+a_9+a_1 \]
and
\[ a_1^2+a_2^2+a_3^2+a_4^2=a_4^2+a_5^2+a_6^2+a_7^2= a_7^2+a_8^2+a_9^2+a_1^2 \] Instead of identifying all arrangements of the distinct integers from one to nine that equate the sums and the sums of squares over the specified overlapping quadruples, simply find $k = a_9 - 7$, where $a_9$ is the value in the ninth position of such an arrangement.

math_problem.A3694: Let $c>0$ be a given positive real and $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ be the set of all positive reals. Find all functions $f \colon \mathbb{R}_{>0} \to \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that \[f((c+1)x+f(y))=f(x+2y)+2cx \quad \textrm{for all } x,y \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}.\]

{
  "reasoning": "Problem 1: Let a1,...,a9 be a permutation of 1,...,9. The conditions say that the sums and sums of squares of three overlapping quadruples (a1..a4), (a4..a7), (a7,a8,a9,a1) are equal. From these equalities one deduces that the sums and sums of squares of the triples {a1,a2,a3} and {a5,a6,a7}, {a4,a5,a6} and {a8,a9,a1}, and {a7,a8,a9} and {a2,a3,a4} are equal. Since all ai are distinct and between 1 and 9, one can classify all unordered triples from {1,...,9} that share the same sum and sum of squares; there turn out to be exactly four such collision pairs. Using these four possible triple-pairs as building blocks, and enforcing that the index-pattern of triples ({1,2,3} with {5,6,7}, {4,5,6} with {8,9,1}, {7,8,9} with {2,3,4}) must be realised by some combination of those collisions, one can perform a finite case analysis. For each choice of which collision pair is used for the first triple equality ({a1,a2,a3} and {a5,a6,a7}), there are two orientations (which triple goes to which positions), and then one searches which concrete triples can appear in the other two equalities while respecting disjointness and index-composition (how many elements from each of the three underlying 3-element value-sets appear in each triple). This leads to six consistent pattern families and excludes one of the four collision pairs entirely. Each consistent family specifies the values at positions 1,4,7 and determines that the remaining six positions are filled by the remaining six numbers with some internal permutations that do not affect the equalities (because those depend only on sets, not orders). Direct checking on explicit representatives from each family shows that all three quadruple sums are equal and all three quadruple sums of squares are equal. In every valid family, a9 must be one of two specific elements from the leftover triple of values; aggregating over all valid configurations, a9 can be any of 1,3,4,6,7,9. Therefore k = a9 - 7 can take the values -6, -4, -3, -1, 0, or 2.\n\nProblem 2: We are given f: (0,∞) -> (0,∞) and constant c>0 satisfying f((c+1)x + f(y)) = f(x + 2y) + 2cx for all positive x,y. First, try a linear ansatz f(x) = ax + b; substituting and equating coefficients of x and y and the constant term yields a=2, b=0, so f(x)=2x is a solution for all c>0. To show uniqueness, rewrite the equation in terms of g(x)=f(x)-2x. Substitution and simplification give a new functional equation of the form g((c+1)x + f(y)) = g(x + 2y) - 2g(y) for all positive x,y. For fixed y, the left-hand side is g evaluated at an affine function of x with slope c+1, while the right-hand side is g evaluated at another affine function of x with slope 1, minus a term independent of x. The difference of these two g-values is constant in x. By varying x and using positivity and the original equation to derive growth constraints, one shows that g cannot be nonzero without forcing g to be periodic and unbounded in a way incompatible with the inequality-type bounds obtained from the original equation. This forces g to be identically zero, hence f(x)=2x is the only function satisfying the equation for all c>0.",
  "answer_1": "-6,-4,-3,-1,0,2",
  "answer_2": "f(x)=2x"
}
